questions.description: Misses details or makes careless mistakes when reading or reviewing work.
Finds it hard to sustain attention in tasks, meetings, or long reading.
Loses track of steps when interrupted and struggles to resume.
Frequently misplaces essentials (keys, phone, cards, badges).
Underestimates or overestimates time; often late or far too early.
Avoids tasks that demand sustained mental effort (planning, forms, long emails).
Starts tasks but leaves them half-finished unless supervised or reminded.
Forgets appointments or deadlines without external reminders.
Feels restless or fidgety and needs to change posture frequently.
Talks a lot or blurts out answers before questions finish.
Interrupts conversations or finishes other people's sentences.
Struggles to wait turns in lines, meetings, or games.
Acts on impulses (buying, messaging, deciding) and regrets it afterward.
Leaves a task to jump into another when bored, even if the first was important.
Chases new ideas or projects and drops current ones abruptly.
Needs to move (walk, tap, stretch) to stay focused.
Hyperfocuses on interesting tasks and loses track of time or basic needs.
Mood shifts quickly across the day depending on stimulation or stress.
Gets irritated easily by delays, noise, or changes to plans.
Has difficulty winding down to sleep because the mind keeps racing.
Organizational systems collapse quickly; clutter piles up.
Needs external prompts (timers, people) to start or finish tasks.
Reacts strongly to minor setbacks or criticism.
Prioritizes poorly; spends time on low-impact tasks while urgent ones wait.

carreras.description: Use visual checklists, time estimates, and reduce distractions. Long-form tasks: break into steps and batch reminders. Seek clinical input if this impacts daily functioning.
Plan movement breaks, practice pause-breathe-choose before acting, and rehearse conversational turns. Clinical support can help with impulsivity and restlessness.
Timebox work (Pomodoro), set external starters/finishers, and log small wins. A specialist can tailor strategies for sleep hygiene, emotion regulation, and prioritization.

labels.HeroSubtitle: Not a diagnosis. Use it to spot patterns and discuss them with a clinician.
labels.ResultsTitle: Areas where you report more symptoms
labels.MethodNote: Personal screening tool. Not a diagnosis. Draws on DSM-5/ASRS-informed items and executive-function checklists to support clinical conversations.
labels.MethodSummaryScoring: Percent is based on your "yes" responses per dimension; more "yes" means higher reported frequency.
